column1: 000000842|Abilities|Reanimation Protocols|Should a Necron be slain
column2: its body becomes wreathed in an eerie glow. Crawling limbs reattach. Sundered torsos and smashed skulls reform amidst emerald sparks. Witchlights flare back to life within dead eye-lenses and the Necron rises again
column3: shambling back into their battle line. Those Necrons too catastrophically damaged to reform vanish instead
column4: teleported away to their tombs for repair.|false|NEC|Each time an enemy unit shoots or fights
column5: after it makes its attacks
column6: if any models in this unit were destroyed as a result of those attacks but this unit was not destroyed
column7:
this unit's reanimation protocols are enacted and those destroyed models begin to reassemble.

Each time a unit's reanimation protocols are enacted
column8:
make Reanimation Protocol rolls for that unit by rolling a number of D6 equal to the combined Wounds characteristics of all the reassembling models. Each Reanimation Protocol roll of 5+ is put into a pool. A Reanimation Protocol roll can never be modified by more than -1 or +1.

If the number of dice in that pool is greater than or equal to the Wounds characteristic of any of the reassembling models
column9:
select one of those models to be Reanimated. A Reanimated model:
  • Is added back to its unit with its full wounds remaining.
  • Can only set up within Engagement Range of enemy units that are already within Engagement Range of the Reanimated model's unit.
  • Cannot
column10: if it is your Charge phase
column11:
be set up closer to any enemy units that are targets of a charge declared by its unit this phase.
  • No longer counts as having been destroyed for the purposes of Morale tests this turn.
    • You then reduce the number of dice in that pool by a number equal to the Wounds characteristic of the Reanimated model and repeat this process until either there are no more reassembling models
column12: or the number of dice remaining in the pool is less than the Wounds characteristic of any of the reassembling models. Any models that did not Reanimate fail to reassemble
column13:
and any dice remaining in the pool are discarded.

Example: In the Shooting phase
column14: an enemy unit targets and makes its attacks against a 5-strong unit of Lychguard
column15: destroying 3 models and leaving another with only one wound left. The Lychguard units reanimation protocols are enacted
column16: and you now make Reanimation Protocol rolls for it. Each Lychguard has a Wounds characteristic of 2
column17: so you would roll a total of six D6s. If you rolled 1
column22: you would put three dice into a pool. This pool contains enough dice to Reanimate one of the destroyed models
column23: and so it is set back up on the battlefield. After that model has been Reanimated
column24: there is only one dice remaining in your pool. This is not enough to Reanimate another reassembling Lychguard model
column25: as it is less than the models Wounds characteristic; this dice is therefore discarded.|

If a unit makes a Battle Focus move and any of its models wish to move over any part of an Area Terrain feature
column17: subtract 3" from the distance models in that unit can move when making that Battle Focus move (to a minimum of 0). This penalty applies even if every part of that Area Terrain feature is 1" or less in height
column18:
but is not cumulative with any other penalties that Area Terrain feature may impose (e.g. the Difficult Ground terrain trait).
Designers Note: Battle Focus and Area Terrain
There are several abilities in Codex: Aeldari which allow units to ignore modifiers to certain moves (such as the Alaitoc Fieldcraft Craftworld Attribute) or move a set distance (such as the Matchless Agility Stratagem). It should be noted that none of these abilities allow a player to ignore the penalty to Battle Focus moves incurred for moving through Area Terrain.|

column1: 000001507|Abilities|Acts of Faith|Through the prayers of the faithful is the Emperor’s will made manifest.|false|AS|Once per phase
column2: one unit from your army with this ability can perform one Act of Faith. To do so
column3:
you will use Miracle dice.

Gaining Miracle Dice
If every unit from your army has the ADEPTA SORORITAS keyword (excluding models with the CULT IMPERIALIS
column4: AGENT OF THE IMPERIUM or UNALIGNED keywords)
column5:
then:
  • At the start of each turn
column6:
you gain 1 Miracle dice.
  • At the end of a phase in which any of the following conditions were met
column7:
you gain 1 Miracle dice:
Vengeance
Any ADEPTA SORORITAS units from your army destroy one or more enemy units.

Sacrifice
Any ADEPTA SORORITAS CHARACTER units from your army are destroyed.

Note that Miracle dice can also be gained via other rules. No matter the source
column8: you can only gain Miracle dice from such a rule if every unit from your army has the ADEPTA SORORITAS keyword (excluding models with the CULT IMPERIALIS
column9:
AGENT OF THE IMPERIUM or UNALIGNED keywords).

Each time you gain a Miracle dice
column10: roll one D6. The number you roll is the value of that Miracle dice. This value cannot be changed or re-rolled
column11:
unless a rule specifically states otherwise. Keep your Miracle dice to one side - this is your Miracle dice pool.

Designer’s Note: We recommend using differently coloured or marked dice for your Miracle dice pool
column12: and placing them to one side of the battle.field
column13: or some place else where you will not accidentally pick them up midgame. It is perfectly fine
column14: if you wish
column15: to write down the values of the Miracle dice in your pool
column16: or to keep track of them in any other way
column17:
just so long as both players can see them.

Performing an Act of Faith
Before making a dice roll for a model or a unit from your army with the Acts of Faith ability
column18: if you have one or more dice in your Miracle dice pool
column19: that unit can perform an Act of Faith. To do so
column20: select one or more of the dice from your Miracle dice pool
column21: instead of making any or all of those dice rolls. For each individual dice that is being rolled as part of the dice roll
column22: you can select 1 Miracle dice from your Miracle dice pool to be substituted in place of that dice. The dice that it is being substituted for is not rolled
column23: and instead the value of the selected Miracle dice is used as if it had been rolled. Each Miracle dice can only be selected for substitution once. Once all Miracle dice substitutions have been made
column24: remove the chosen Miracle dice from your Miracle dice pool
column26:
unsubstituted dice that are a part of the dice roll. You can use Miracle dice when a unit performs an Act of Faith for any of the following types of dice roll:
  • Advance roll
  • Charge roll
  • Hit roll
  • Wound roll
  • Saving throw
  • Damage roll
  • Morale test
A Miracle dice is not a modifier or an inherently modified dice (so
column28: if you use a Miracle dice with a value of 1 for a Morale test
column29: that is considered to be an unmodified roll of 1). A Miracle dice that has been used for a substitution can never be re-rolled. This means that if any re-rolls occur
column30: the number and values of any Miracle dice that have already been substituted in the dice roll remain the same for the re-roll (for example
column31: if a single Miracle dice was used to substitute one of the values of a charge roll
column32: and the charge roll was re-rolled
column33:
only the unsubstituted dice can be re-rolled).

Example 1: Instead of rolling one D6 to see what value is added to a unit’s Move characteristic when that unit Advances
column34: you could use a dice from your Miracle dice pool. If the value of that dice was 5
column35:
you would add 5" to the Move characteristic of every model in that unit for that Movement phase.

Example 2: Instead of rolling 2D6 to see what a unit’s charge distance is when making a charge roll
column36: you could use either one or two dice from your Miracle dice pool. If you chose 2 Miracle dice
column37: and the values of those dice were a 6 and a 3
column38: the unit’s charge distance would be 9".|

column1: 000001708|Abilities|Daemonic Ritual|Through dark pacts and blasphemous rituals
column2: a champion of Chaos can weaken the fabric of reality to create a gateway to the warp. From this rent pour forth the Daemons of that realm
column3: ready to rend and tear those who stand against the Ruinous Powers.|false|CD|Instead of moving in their Movement phase
column4: any CHAOS CHARACTER can
column5: at the end of their Movement phase
column6: attempt to summon a DAEMON unit with this ability by performing a Daemonic Ritual (the character cannot do so if they arrived as reinforcements this turn
column7:
or if they were themselves summoned to the battlefield this turn).

If they do so
column8: first choose one of the four Chaos Gods – KHORNE
column9: TZEENTCH
column10: NURGLE or SLAANESH. A CHARACTER who owes allegiance to one of the Dark Gods can only attempt to summon the units of their patron – for example
column11:
a KHORNE CHARACTER could only attempt to summon KHORNE DAEMONS.

Roll up to 3 dice – this is your summoning roll. You can summon one new unit with the Daemonic Ritual ability to the battlefield that has a Power Rating equal to or less than the total result so long as it has the same Chaos God keyword you chose at the start (in the case of units that have a choice of allegiance
column12: such as Furies
column13: the unit when summoned will have this keyword). This unit is treated as reinforcements for your army and can be placed anywhere on the battlefield that is wholly within 12" of the character and more than 9" from any enemy model. If the total rolled is insufficient to summon any unit
column14:
the ritual fails and no new unit is summoned.

If your summoning roll included any doubles
column15: your character then suffers a mortal wound. If it contained any triples
column16: it instead suffers D3 mortal wounds.|

column1: 000002038||Void Shields||false|DG|This model has 2 void shields. Each void shield has 3 shield points. While this model has any void shields
column2:
it has a 5+ invulnerable save against ranged attacks.

Each time a saving throw is failed for this model against a ranged attack
column3: if it has any void shields
column4: it does not suffer any damage. Instead
column5: for each point of damage inflicted
column6: one of its void shields loses 1 shield point. Once a void shield has lost a shield point
column7: it must continue to lose shield points due to any further damage inflicted until it collapses. Each time an attack causes a void shield to be reduced to 0 shield points
column8:
that void shield collapses: this model loses that void shield and any excess damage inflicted by that attack is lost. Void shields can never be used to prevent mortal wounds (each mortal wound inflicted on a model with void shields causes that model to lose one wound as normal).

At the start of your Command phase
column9: if this model has a void shield that has fewer than 3 shield points remaining
column10: that void shield is restored to 3 shield points.|

it is not returned to the unit).

Aegis of the Emperor
Devotion value 3
Use this Act of Faith at the start of your opponent’s Psychic phase. If successful
column15: then until the end of that phase
column16:
roll a D6 each time the selected unit suffers a mortal wound. On a 4+ that mortal wound is ignored.

Divine Guidance
Devotion value 4
Use this Act of Faith at the start of your Shooting phase. If successful
column17:
add 1 to hit rolls for attacks made with this unit’s ranged weapons until the end of the phase.

The Passion
Devotion value 5
Use this Act of Faith at the start of your Fight phase. If successful
column18: the selected unit can be chosen to Fight with twice in that phase
column19:
instead of only once.

Light of the Emperor
Devotion value 3

column20: the selected unit automatically passes Morale tests that phase.|

For the purposes of the Bolter Discipline ability
column6: performing actions
column7: the Deathwatch teleport homer wargear
column8: and for determining which models can embark within a TRANSPORT model
column9:
the following rules apply:
  • Deathwatch Terminator and Terminator models have the TERMINATOR keyword.
  • Veteran Biker models do not have the INFANTRY keyword and instead have the BIKER keyword.
  • Vanguard Veteran models with jump packs have the JUMP PACK keyword.
  • Inceptor models have the JUMP PACK keyword.
  • Outrider models do not have the INFANTRY keyword and instead have the BIKER keyword.
Vanguard Veterans with jump packs and Inceptors can move across terrain as if they have the FLY keyword.

Note that for the purposes of interacting with terrain features
column10: if this unit contains at least one INFANTRY model
column11: all models in this unit are treated as INFANTRY
column12:
even if this unit contains any BIKER models that might behave differently or have specific restrictions whilst interacting with a terrain feature.

Designer’s Note: This is a slight abstraction that means that a BIKER model in a mixed unit behaves slightly differently to BIKER models in other units
column13: but it helps to minimise unusual and complicated effects that could come about from forcing one model from a unit to move and benefit from cover in a different way to other models from the same unit.|

column1: 000004698|Abilities|Command Protocols|The Necron nobility make war in a codified and relentless fashion. Their command protocols crackle out across multi-dimensional spectra from carrier-wave projectors
column2:
compelling their semi-sentient soldiery into battle one overriding directive at a time.|false|NEC|
If every unit from your army (excluding DYNASTIC AGENT
column3: C’TAN SHARD and UNALIGNED units) is from the same dynasty
column4: and you select a NECRONS CHARACTER model to be your WARLORD
column5:
this unit is eligible to benefit from this ability and the following rules apply.

After both sides have deployed
column6: but before you have determined who will have the first turn
column7: you must assign a different one of the command protocols below to each of the first five battle rounds
column8:
and note this down secretly on your army roster.

Example: Matts army is led by an Overlord (a NECRONS CHARACTER)
column9: and every model in it is from the same dynasty
column10: therefore he must assign command protocols. He selects the following
column11:
writing them down on his army roster:
  • Battle Round 1 = 2 (Sudden Storm)
  • Battle Round 2 = 3 (Vengeful Stars)
  • Battle Round 3 = 5 (Undying Legions)
  • Battle Round 4 = 4 (Hungry Void)
  • Battle Round 5+ = 1 (Eternal Guardian)
Designers Note: If you have a set of Necrons Datacards
column12:
you can instead assign your command protocols by selecting the five corresponding cards you wish to use and placing them in a face-down deck in an order such that - by turning over the top card at the start of each battle round - you reveal the command protocol that will be active for your army that battle round.

At the start of each battle round
column13: if any NECRONS CHARACTER units from your army are on the battlefield
column14: the command protocol that you assigned to that battle round becomes active for your army until the end of that battle round. Each command protocol is made up of two directives. When a command protocol becomes active for your army
column15: reveal it to your opponent and select one of its directives. Until the assigned command protocol stops being active
column16: while a unit that is eligible to benefit from this ability is on the battlefield
column17:
that unit benefits from the selected directive.

In addition
column18: if all units from your army are from the same dynasty (excluding DYNASTIC AGENT
column19: C’TAN SHARD and UNALIGNED units)
column20: select one command protocol that has not been assigned to a battle round (there will typically only be one). That command protocol is active in every battle round in addition to the one assigned to that battle round – select which directive your units will benefit from at the start of each battle round. Note that if this additional command protocol is the one described in your dynasty’s code
column21: this means both of its directives apply to all units with this ability in your army in every battle round
column22:
in addition to the protocol assigned to that battle round. The available command protocols are shown below.

Designer’s Note: Some rules refer to ‘the active command protocol’
column23:
in these instances these rules refer to all command protocols that are active for your army.
$Table$

column1: 000004973||Void Shields||false|HTL|This model has 6 void shields. Each void shield has 3 shield points. While this model has any void shields
column2:
it has a 5+ invulnerable save against ranged attacks.

Each time a saving throw is failed for this model against a ranged attack
column3: if it has any void shields
column4: it does not suffer any damage. Instead
column5: for each point of damage inflicted
column6: one of its void shields loses 1 shield point. Once a void shield has lost a shield point
column7: it must continue to lose shield points due to any further damage inflicted until it collapses. Each time an attack causes a void shield to be reduced to 0 shield points
column8:
that void shield collapses: this model loses that void shield and any excess damage inflicted by that attack is lost. Void shields can never be used to prevent mortal wounds (each mortal wound inflicted on a model with void shields causes that model to lose one wound as normal).

At the start of your Command phase
column9: if this model has a void shield that has fewer than 3 shield points remaining
column10: that void shield is restored to 3 shield points.|

column1: 000005014||Void Shields||false|TS|This model has 2 void shields. Each void shield has 3 shield points. While this model has any void shields
column2:
it has a 5+ invulnerable save against ranged attacks.

Each time a saving throw is failed for this model against a ranged attack
column3: if it has any void shields
column4: it does not suffer any damage. Instead
column5: for each point of damage inflicted
column6: one of its void shields loses 1 shield point. Once a void shield has lost a shield point
column7: it must continue to lose shield points due to any further damage inflicted until it collapses. Each time an attack causes a void shield to be reduced to 0 shield points
column8:
that void shield collapses: this model loses that void shield and any excess damage inflicted by that attack is lost. Void shields can never be used to prevent mortal wounds (each mortal wound inflicted on a model with void shields causes that model to lose one wound as normal).

At the start of your Command phase
column9: if this model has a void shield that has fewer than 3 shield points remaining
column10: that void shield is restored to 3 shield points.|

column1: 000005016||Explodes||false|TS|When this model is destroyed

column3:
and each unit within D6+6" suffers D6 mortal wounds.

Designers Note: If this model does not have a base
column4: before deploying this model
column5:
both players must agree the footprint of this model’s ‘base’ in the same way they would for an Area Terrain feature. We suggest that an imaginary straight line should be drawn from each point on this model which would touch the battlefield when it is placed on a flat surface. The area within these lines should be considered to be this model’s ‘base’.

If the model has been posed with one or more of its legs raised
column6: agree with your opponent the point where that leg would touch the battlefield
column7: and use this to advise the shape of the models ‘base’.|

Contagion Abilities
Contagion abilities affect enemy models or units within Contagion Range - this changes with the battle round number

column15: identically named Contagion abilities is not cumulative (i.e. if an enemy unit is within range of two models with the same Contagion ability
column16: that Contagion ability only applies to the enemy unit once). Note
column17: that while similar in many regards to Aura abilities
column18: Contagion abilities are not affected by abilities that affect Aura abilities
column19:

column1: 000005745|Abilities|Waaagh!|This infamous war cry is known and feared throughout the galaxy. When it echoes across the battlefield
column2: bellowed from hundreds or even thousands of greenskin mouths

even the most stalwart warriors fear the onslaught to come.|false|ORK|
If your WARLORD is a WARBOSS
column4: then once per battle
column5: in your Command phase
column6: you can call a Waaagh!. To do so
column7: that WARBOSS must be on the battlefield or embarked on a TRANSPORT that is on the battlefield. If your WARLORD is a SPEEDBOSS
column8: then once per battle
column9: in your Command phase
column10: you can instead call a Speedwaaagh!. To do so
column11: that SPEEDBOSS must be on the battlefield. If your WARLORD is GHAZGHKULL THRAKA
column12: you can instead call a Great Waaagh!. To do so
column13:
GHAZGHKULL THRAKA must be on the battlefield or embarked on a TRANSPORT that is on the battlefield.

A Waaagh! and Speedwaaagh! each have two stages. The first stage is active from when the Waaagh! or Speedwaaagh! is called
column14: and lasts until the start of your next Command phase. When the first stage ends
column15: the second stage starts
column16: and lasts until the start of your subsequent Command phase. After this point
column17: the Waaagh! or Speedwaaagh! is no longer active
column18: and has no further effect. Calling a Great Waaagh! is treated as calling both a Waaagh! and a Speedwaaagh! at the same time. Both are active from when a Great Waaagh! is called
column19:
and each stage starts and finishes as described above.

Waaagh!

Raising his weapons into the air before gesturing towards the enemy
column20: the Warboss bellows his war cry. Every nearby Ork joins in before surging towards the enemy
column21:
blades ready in an overwhelming tide.

Stage 1: Call Da Waaagh!
  • ORKS CORE and ORKS CHARACTER units from your army are eligible to declare a charge even if they Advanced this turn.
  • Add 1 to the Strength and Attacks characteristics of ORKS models from your army.
  • ORKS models from your army have a 5+ invulnerable save.
Stage 2: Get Stuck In!
  • Add 1 to the Strength and Attacks characteristics of ORKS models from your army.
  • ORKS models from your army have a 6+ invulnerable save.

Speedwaaagh!

As the wind and the bullets of the foe whistle past his vehicle
column22: the Speedboss throws back his head and roars his war cry
column23:
the call echoing from the ramshackle vehicles following in his wake as they surge forward ever faster.

Stage 1: Da Big Race
  • ORKS models from your army do not suffer the penalty incurred to their hit rolls for firing Assault weapons in the same turn their unit Advanced. Each time an ORKS VEHICLE or ORKS BIKER model from your army shoots with a Dakka weapon
column24:
make 1 additional attack with that weapon.
  • Each time a model in an ORKS VEHICLE or ORKS BIKER unit from your army makes a ranged attack
column25:
improve the Armour Penetration characteristic of that attack by 1.
Stage 2: Give ’Em Sum Dakka!
  • Each time a model in an ORKS VEHICLE or ORKS BIKER unit from your army makes a ranged attack
column26: improve the Armour Penetration characteristic of that attack by 1.|

and each unit from your army can only benefit from one Cabbalistic Ritual. A unit can only benefit from a Cabbalistic Ritual if it has this ability.

Note that when a Cabbalistic Ritual specifies a ‘unit from your army’ with regard to when it can be used (e.g. ‘when a unit from your army is selected to manifest psychic powers’)
column25:
that Cabbalistic Ritual can only be used if that unit has the THOUSAND SONS keyword.
IMBUED MANIFESTATION
4 Cabal Points

Like flame leaping along a trail of spilled promethium
column26:
the Thousand Sons’ magicks feed upon the latent energies clouding the air and race hungrily away through them towards the foe.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual when a psychic power is successfully manifested by a unit from your army. Add 6" to the range of that psychic power’s effects (if that psychic power specifies multiple ranges
column28:
add 6" to the first range specified in that psychic power).

MALEVOLENT CHARGE
4 Cabal Points

The malefic energies of dark sorcery flow together in ever more lethal concentrations into fiery
column29:
mutating storms.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual when a psychic power is successfully manifested by a unit from your army. If the psychic power inflicts mortal wounds on enemy units
column30:
after inflicting the mortal wounds select one of those units and inflict D3 additional mortal wounds on that unit.

KINDRED SORCERERS
5 Cabal Points

For an instant
column31: the chanting voices of the Thousand Sons’ champions achieve perfect synchronisation
column32:
words of malign incantation rolling out like the peal of some cursed bell.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual after taking a Psychic test for a unit from your army. Add 1 to that Psychic test.

WARP SIGHT
3 Cabal Points

With their tainted souls melded as one amidst the empyrean
column33: what one champion of the cabal sees
column34:
all their fellows see also.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual when a psychic power is successfully manifested by a unit from your army. If the psychic power requires you to select a unit visible to the PSYKER
column35:
for that manifestation you can select a unit visible to any friendly unit with the Cabbalistic Rituals ability.

ECHOES FROM THE WARP
4 Cabal Points

Plucked from amidst the howling winds of the immaterium and the gibbering of countless damned voices come whispers of invaluable daemonic prophecy.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual in your Psychic phase. Select one PSYKER unit from your army. Until the end of the phase
column36: that unit can perform the following psychic action: Echoes From the Warp (Psychic Action - Warp Charge 3): If successful
column37:
gain 1 Command point.

PACT FROM BEYOND
7 Cabal Points

Though it is always perilous to make deals with the entities of the warp
column38:
the support of one’s cabal ameliorates the risks somewhat.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual when attempting to manifest a psychic power with a unit from your army. Do not make a Psychic test: that Psychic test is passed at the minimum required warp charge value.

CABBALISTIC FOCUS
8 Cabal Points

With the champions of the cabal incanting as one
column39:
their sorceries become an unstoppable tidal wave.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual after a Psychic test made for a unit from your army is passed. That psychic power or psychic action cannot be denied.

PSYCHIC MAELSTROM
8 Cabal Points

By establishing a recursive temporal loop
column40:
the cabal are able to lash the enemy with the same terrible moment of loss over and over again.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual when a unit from your army is selected to manifest psychic powers. Until the end of the phase
column41: that unit can attempt to manifest one Witchfire psychic power that another PSYKER in your army has already attempted to manifest during the phase
column42: even though the same psychic power cannot normally be attempted more than once per Psychic phase
column43:
and even if that unit does not know that psychic power.

WRATH OF THE IMMATERIUM
9 Cabal Points

Such is the aura of latent energy roiling at the cabal’s command
column44:
it is as though the daemons of the warp lend their own unnatural power to the champions’ conjurations.

Use this Cabbalistic Ritual after taking a Psychic test for a unit from your army. Add 2 to that Psychic test.|

column1:
000006209|Martial Ka’tah|Martial Ka’tah||false|AC|
If every unit from your army has the ADEPTUS CUSTODES keyword (excluding ANATHEMA PSYKANA
column2: AGENT OF THE IMPERIUM and UNALIGNED units)
column3: and every unit that is assigned to a shield host is assigned to the same shield host
column4:
this unit can use this ability and the following rules apply.

After both sides have deployed
column5: but before you have determined who will have the first turn
column6: you must select a primary
column7:
secondary and tertiary martial ka’tah from the list below for your army to use in the battle. Note this down secretly on your army roster.

In each of your Command phases
column8: so long as one is available
column9: you must select one ka’tah stance to become active for your army. Each time you do so
column10: units from your army with this ability benefit from it until the start of your next Command phase. When selecting a ka’tah stance to become active
column11:
the following rules apply:
  • You cannot select a ka’tah stance more than once.
  • You must select a primary ka’tah stance first
column12:
and you cannot select a tertiary ka’tah stance until you have selected a secondary ka’tah stance.
  • Once you select a stance of a different martial ka’tah
column13: you cannot select a stance of a previous martial ka’tah.Example: Every model in Emily’s army has the ADEPTUS CUSTODES keyword. She selects Rendax as her primary ka’tah
column14: Dacatarai as her secondary ka’tah and Calistus as her tertiary ka’tah. In her first command phase
column15:
she selects Rendax stance 2 to be active.

In her second Command phase
column16: she can select Rendax stance 1 to be active
column17: or she can instead select Dacatarai stance 1 or 2 to be active
column18: as she has previously selected a primary ka’tah stance. She cannot select a Calistus stance
column19:
as she must select a secondary ka’tah’s stance before she can select a tertiary ka’tah’s stance. She selects Dacatarai stance 1 to be active.

In her third Command phase
column20: she can select Dacatarai stance 2 to be active
column21: or she can instead select Calistus stance 1 or 2 to be active
column22: as she has previously selected a secondary ka’tah stance. She cannot select Rendax stance 1
column23:
as she cannot select a stance of a previous ka’tah. She selects Calistus stance 2 to be active.

In her fourth Command phase
column24: she must select Calistus stance 1 to be active
column25: as it is the only remaining stance she is able to select. Note that this means in the fifth Command phase
column26: there would be no ka’tah stances available to her
column27: so she does not select one.|

column1: 000006255|Abilities|Conceal|Genestealer Cults keep their fighting strength carefully hidden from their oppressors until the glorious day of ascension arrives.|false|GC|During deployment
column2: you can set up this unit in ambush instead of setting it up on the battlefield. If this unit is an INFANTRY or BIKER unit
column3:
you can set up this unit underground instead of setting it up on the battlefield or in ambush.

Ambush
Ambush marker
If you set up this unit in ambush
column4:
place an ambush marker anywhere on the battlefield that is wholly within your deployment zone.

Units set up in ambush are considered to be set up on the battlefield (unless they are embarked within a TRANSPORT model that is set up in ambush)
column5:
even though their models are not actually on the battlefield. Enemy models cannot be set up or moved within 9" of the centre of any of your ambush markers.

Underground
If this unit is set up underground
column6: then in the Reinforcements step of one of your Movement phases
column7:
you can set up this unit under one of the following conditions:
  • You can set up this unit anywhere on the battlefield that is more than 8" away from any enemy models.
  • You can set up this unit anywhere on the battlefield that is more than 6" away from any enemy models
column8: but that unit is not eligible to declare a charge this turn.If a unit set up underground has any abilities that are used in your Command phase (e.g. Meticulous Planner)
column9: then the first time that unit is set up on the battlefield
column10:
it can use any or all of those abilities as if it were your Command phase.

Units set up underground are considered to be set up in a location other than the battlefield
column11:
therefore this must be determined in the Declare Reserves and Transports step of a mission sequence that includes such a step.

Revealing Ambush Markers
In the first battle round:
  • If you have the first turn
column12:
you must reveal all of your ambush markers at the start of your Command phase.
  • If you do not have the first turn
column13: you must reveal all of your ambush markers at the end of your opponents Movement phase.To reveal an ambush marker
column14:
select one unit from your army that was set up in ambush and has not yet been set up from an ambush marker:
  • Set up one model from that unit within 1" of the centre of that ambush marker
column15:
wholly within your deployment zone and more than 9" away from any enemy models. Then remove that ambush marker.
  • Set up the remaining models in that unit wholly within 6" of the first model
column16: wholly within your deployment zone and more than 9" away from any enemy models.Units set up from an ambush marker do not count as Reinforcements. After all units from your army that were set up in ambush have been set up from an ambush marker
column17: remove any remaining ambush markers you placed on the battlefield.|

column1: 000006256|Abilities|Crossfire|The inhuman coordination of Genestealer Cultists more than makes up for their motley assortment of weapons and vehicles.|false|GC|If every unit from your army has the GENESTEALER CULTS keyword (excluding UNALIGNED units and the percentage ratio of BROOD BROTHERS units specified here)
column2: and every unit from your army that belongs to a cult belongs to the same cult
column3: this unit can use this ability and the following rules apply. Note that there are rules that enhance or otherwise interact with these Crossfire rules. No matter the source
column4: you can only use such rules if every unit from your army has the GENESTEALER CULTS keyword (excluding UNALIGNED units and the percentage ratio of BROOD BROTHERS units
column5:
and every unit from your army that belongs to a cult belongs to the same cult.

Crossfire Markers
Crossfire marker
In your Shooting phase
column6: each time a CROSSFIRE unit is selected to shoot
column7: if all of those attacks target one enemy unit without a crossfire marker
column8: after resolving those attacks
column9:
the target gains a crossfire marker if any of the following conditions were satisfied:
  • Five or more of those attacks scored a hit.
  • One or more of those attacks with a Damage characteristic other than 1 scored a hit.
At the end of your turn
column10:
remove all crossfire markers enemy units have.

Effects of Crossfire
  • Each time a CROSSFIRE model makes a ranged attack
column11: if the target unit has a crossfire marker
column12:
add 1 to that attack’s hit roll.
  • Each time a CROSSFIRE model makes a ranged attack
column13: if the target unit has a crossfire marker and was Exposed when it was selected as the target (see below)
column14:
add 1 to that attack’s wound roll.
  • Each time a CROSSFIRE model makes a ranged attack
column15: if the target unit has a crossfire marker
column16: was Exposed when it was selected as the target
column17: and was within 12" when it was selected as the target
column18:
the target does not receive the benefits of cover against that attack.
Exposed
To determine if a target unit is Exposed
column19:
draw a line from any part of the base (or hull) of one model in the attacking CROSSFIRE unit to any part of the base (or hull) of one model in another friendly CROSSFIRE unit that is visible to that model (as shown in the diagrams below). The target unit is Exposed if both of the following conditions are satisfied:
  • That line passes over any part of the base (or hull) of one or more models in the target unit.
  • That line does not pass over a terrain feature with the Obscuring terrain trait (unless those CROSSFIRE units or the target unit are on or within that terrain feature
column20: or the target unit could still be targeted even if a terrain feature with the Obscuring terrain trait was between it and an attacking model
column21: e.g. it is an AIRCRAFT unit
column22: it has a Wounds characteristic of 18 or more

you must select the Doom ability.

column1: 000007882|Abilities|Voice of Command|Raised and trained to instil unwavering obedience
column2: officers of the Imperial Guard command authority and respect and issue orders with imperious bellows that cut through the clamour of war.|false|AM|In your Command phase
column3: ASTRA MILITARUM OFFICERS from your army can issue Orders. There are three types of Orders - Regimental Orders
column4: Prefectus Orders and Mechanised Orders. The Commanding Authority section of each OFFICER’s datasheet will specify which types of Orders that OFFICER knows
column5:
and how many Orders it can issue per turn.

Each time an OFFICER issues an Order
column6: you must select one of the Orders it knows. This can be an Order that was already issued by another friendly OFFICER this turn
column7:
but the same OFFICER cannot attempt to issue the same Order more than once in the same battle round.

You must then select a target unit for that Order to be issued to. If issuing a Regimental or Prefectus Order
column8: select one friendly PLATOON unit within 6" of that OFFICER’s unit. If issuing a Mechanised Order
column9:
select one friendly SQUADRON unit within 12" of that OFFICER’s unit.

The unit you selected is then affected by that Order. A unit can only be affected by one Order at a time. If a unit is being affected by an Order when it is selected to be affected by another Order
column10:
the new Order immediately replaces the old one.

  • OFFICERS can issue Orders in your Command phase.
  • The types of Order an OFFICER knows and the number they can issue are described on their datasheet.
  • Regimental and Prefectus Orders: select one friendly PLATOON unit within 6".
  • Mechanised Orders: select one friendly SQUADRON unit within 12".
  • A unit can only be affected by one Order at a time.
